_exec_summary.SummaryText:
MARATHON KENAI REFINERY
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
RMP Resubmittal - September 2024

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 

This Risk Management Plan Executive Summary was developed pursuant to Environmental Protection Agencys Risk Management Plan (EPA RMP) (Title 40 CFR Part 68). The purpose of this Executive Summary is to provide a brief description of certain elements of the Risk Management Plan that has been implemented at the Marathon Kenai Refinery, located in Kenai, Alaska. The objectives of the EPA Risk Management Plan (RMP) are to prevent chemical accidents, mitigate their effects, enhance emergency response capabilities, promote public awareness, ensure regulatory compliance, and support continuous improvement in chemical safety.

1.0 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES 

The Marathon Kenai Refinery (Refinery) has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.

2.0 DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES 

The Marathon Kenai Refinery, located in Nikiski, Alaska, operates a variety of processes to produce petroleum products (e.g., natural gas, propane, butane, and gasoline) from crude oil. The refinery uses or produces several regulated flammables, such as pentane, propane and butane. Marathon calculated the quantity of RMP regulated substances using detailed engineering calculations.

The 2024 Resubmittal includes the 2021 PSM Audit - RMP - investigate discrepancy in flammable ARS and the 2024 separation of the Amine/Flare Gas Recovery Unit to individual units: Amine Unit and Flare Gas Recovery Unit.

3.0 HAZ

ARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY 

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary for Flammables

WCR Scenario Description: The worst-case scenario selected was the Butane Storage Tank (TK-70) in the Tank Farm Unit, which assumes a rupture and release of the entire contents containing 3,300,000 lbs of Flammable Mixture (Propane, Butane, Pentane), causing a vapor cloud explosion. No mitigation measure was considered. Using the parameters mandated by regulations through RMP*Comp Program, this worst-case release has the potential to transverse a 1.2-mile radius from the point of release and the potential to affect the population of 267 people.

Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary for Flammables

ARS Scenario Description: The alternative release scenario selected was the inadvertent opening of a Flow Control Valve in the butane line to the Butane Storage Tank (TK-70) in the Tank Farm Unit, releasing 4,900 lbs. of butane, causing a vapor cloud explosion. No mitigation measures were considered. Using the parameters mandated by regulations through RMP*Comp Program, this alternative release has the potential to transverse 0.09-mile radius from the point of release but with no potential to affect the population.

4.0 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 

At Marathon we are proud of our safety performance. The Kenai Refinery has had an excellent record of accident prevention since the start of our operation in 1969. In fact, we have never experienced an incident that impacted people or property outside of the Refinery since 1969. 

5.0 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS 

The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at the Kenai Refinery. This program includes the required elements of our Process Safety Management (PSM) program. 

Process Safety Information 

The Refinery maintains technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes. The documents address chemical properties and asso

ciated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. Specific departments within the Refinery are assigned responsibility for maintaining up to- date process safety information. 

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDS). This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and any known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals. The Refinery has developed procedures for operating the processes within safe limits for temperature, level, composition, pressure, etc. The Refinery ensures that the processes are maintained within these limits using process controls, monitoring instruments, trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems). 

The Refinery also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised. 

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) 

The Refinery has a comprehensive PHA program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. 

The Refinery primarily uses the hazard and operability (HAZOP) analysis method to perform PHA evaluations. HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of the most syste

matic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques and is considered adequate for the complexity of the processes. The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. The PHA's are facilitated by someone with experience with the selected method. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measure and makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary. 

The PHA team's findings are reviewed and resolved by local management. Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team. This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive immediate attention. All approved mitigation options being implemented in response to PHA team findings are tracked until completion. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained. 

To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, the Refinery periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. Periodic reviews are conducted at least every five years. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained. Once again, the team findings are forwarded to management for consideration, and the final resolution of the findings is documented and retained. 

Operating Procedures 

The Refinery maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as unit startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown, and initial startup of a new process. These procedures are utilized by operators and maintenance personnel and provide a basis for consistent training of new employees. Procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certifi

ed as current and accurate. They are maintained current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the management of change process. 

The operating procedures at the Refinery provide guidance on how to respond to upper or lower limit variances for specific process or equipment parameters. This information, along with written operating procedures, is readily available to operators as electronic files on computers located in the control rooms and in hard copy for all emergency procedures. 

Training 

To complement the written procedures for process operations, the Refinery has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process or working within an RMP-covered process. New employees receive 40 hours of Environmental Health and Safety (EHS) basic training. Personnel in refinery operations receive an additional six weeks of job-specific training. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-related duties and tasks. After operators demonstrate (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. Before operating in a process operators must be certified by demonstrating adequate skill and knowledge in that specific process. All operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted routinely with the maximum time frame to be at least every three years. All of this training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training. All refinery employees are trained on Safe Work Practices in accordance with the Work Practice Training Matrix. 

Mechanical Integrity 

The Refinery has well-established practices and procedures to maintain

iewed and authorized before being implemented. Changes are reviewed to: 

(1) Ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards; 
(2) Verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change; 
(3) Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures are updated to incorporate these changes; and 
(4) Operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on the change. 

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR) 

The Refinery conducts a PSSR for any facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides an additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all systems are operationally ready. The PSSR team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented. PSSR is integrated into the Management of Change (MOC) program and is required for every MOC. 

Compliance Audits 

To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the Refinery periodically conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented. Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years by a Corporate approved/appointed audit team, or a third-party consulting firm mixed with Marathon personnel from across the Corporation. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to Refinery management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolu

tion of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained. 

Incident Investigation 

The Refinery promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably had the potential to have resulted in, a fire, explosion, or toxic gas release, that could have caused major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to Refinery management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least five years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations. 

Employee Participation 

The Refinery encourages employees to participate in all facets of safety management and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team. 

(1) Employees have access to all information created as part of the Refinery Safety Program. 
(2) Regularly held safety meetings in each department are one way in which employees are able to participate in the review and development of programs and work practices. 
(3) An Employee Safety Steering Committee was established to promote employee feedback and participation. This committee is represented by one individual from each department and is responsible for gathering employee feedback and promoting participation. 
(4) Othe

ERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION 

The Kenai Refinery maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect workers and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. The Refinery has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. The emergency response program is updated, when necessary, based on modifications made to refinery processes or other refinery facilities.

The overall emergency response program for the Refinery is coordinated with local emergency responders, such as the fire department and the office of the Alaska State Troopers, as well as state and federal agencies. The Refinery has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate community officials and emergency response organizations. This provides a means of facilitating quick response to an incident, as well as notifying the public of an incident if necessary. The Refinery conducts periodic emergency response exercises that involve refinery personnel, contractors, and emergency response organizations. The refinery provides refresher training to emergency responders regarding their responsibilities during an emergency.

7.0 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Marathon Kenai Refinery is implementing a process called

Human & Organization Performance (HOP) to establish a learning culture and create an environment fully supported by leaders where employees feel empowered to report errors and speak openly about work challenges with the goal of building resilient work processes and systems.  HOP is a philosophy that aims to incorporate existing programs, tools, and behaviors to engage the workforce as problem solvers and create operational learning.

The Marathon Kenai Refinery is implementing a process by which alarms are being used to recognize Not-To-Exceed (NTE) situations when the plant deviates into a state outside its design conditions and enable the Operator to apply procedural response actions to restore a safe condition. Benefits include immediately drawing the Operators attention to that situation above all others and restoring a safe unit condition.
